Patriots release defensive tackle Kyle Love after diabetes diagnosis

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎05-16-2013 07:56 AM

“This comes on the heels of Kyle having been diagnosed within the past two weeks with Type-2 diabetes," Richard Kopelman, Love's agent, told ESPN Boston. "Naturally, we are disappointed that the Patriots decided to part ways with Kyle, especially in light of the fact that a number of elite professional athletes with diabetes – both Type-1, which is known to be far more difficult to manage than Type-2 diabetes – have had very successful careers in professional football, hockey, baseball and basketball.

 

http://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nfl-shutdown-corner/patriots-release-defensive-tackle-kyle-love-diabet...

 

I hope this post does not violate the copyrights rules of this board.

‎05-16-2013 12:46 PM

I know of several professionals who's career was terminated immediately after diagnosis. One was a commercial airline pilot.  I think D2 but severe and Dx'd he was in his late 20's.

 

I've heard about people losing other licenses and privilages, even driving thier private car.  After I thought this might have been unfair to this football player Mr. Love....  then I thought about my own world.

 

What protects me from losing privilages/licensing?  If it were sensible criteria would be based on performance and evenly evaluated. 

 

As if I didn't have enough reason to see very good control, retaining privilages is yet another isn't it?

 

ADA advocacy used to be a sort of mysterious activity to me until recently when my state passed a law that allows school age children to manage thier insulin and BG, to attend school.  That was last month.

 

Would someone convince me please that I won't be discriminated against for having this disease?

Best, to you
Endo said my case behaves like T1, since about age 50, idiopathic: toxicological, or immune mediated. first dx T2 in 2008 by my GP
Now limiting complications via TSlim pump w/Novalog .... Dexcom

Re: Patriots release defensive tackle Kyle Love after diabetes diagnosis

‎05-16-2013 07:40 PM

BentRedRider wrote:

 

Would someone convince me please that I won't be discriminated against for having this disease?


I don't know if you or anyone else will be discriminated against for having diabetes, but I do know that it is against the law to discriminate unreasonably in employment because of it.  If you can do the job with reasonable accommodation, you should be allowed to keep the job.  I also think it likely that the Patriots have attorneys, and that the attorneys reviewed this before signing off on it.  There may be more to this story than the player's agent fed to the "journalist".

 

In any case, if someone can play, some team will give them a chance to play.  There are 31 other teams, and they employ drug addicts and people with extensive criminal records.  They won't have any problem hiring someone with a disease that is not a problem in their play.  And if this player does successfully play for another team, that only strengthens their discrimination suit.  I do think, however, that there may be other reasons behind this.

 

 

George

Diagnosed T2 9/12/12, A1C 10.1
Metformin 500 mg. 1 x daily since 9/17/2012
A1C 12/13/2012 5.6
A1C 3/15/2013 5.4
A1C 11/29/2013 5.5
Weight at diagnosis 9/12/2012 288
Weight 10/01/2013 187

‎05-16-2013 08:38 PM

Bill Bellichek can kiss my white Ohio butt.

 

The ADA is thrilled with Ryan Reed.

Of course, he's just a NASCAR driver. Knot a "Real" athlete. *sarcasm alert*

How would y'all like to take care of your D at 190MPH??

Not bad for some guy who just drives around in circles. *again, major sarcasm alert*

 

"NASCAR Nationwide Series driver Ryan Reed will compete for the first time in the No. 16 Drive to Stop Diabetes Ford Mustang at his first race of the season, scheduled for April 26, 2013 at the Richmond International Raceway. Reed, who is living with type 1 diabetes, recently announced a collaboration with the American Diabetes Association for the Drive to Stop Diabetes℠ awareness campaign.

Drive to Stop Diabetes will feature Reed as the voice of someone living with diabetes and educational efforts at numerous NASCAR Nationwide races, as well as at several off-track health and wellness initiatives, throughout 2013. A Bakersfield, Calif. native who has been racing since the age of four, Reed was diagnosed at the age of 17 with type 1 diabetes. When he was diagnosed, he was told he would never be able to race again which was unacceptable to the young man who has become an advocate for diabetes awareness and started his own foundation, Ryan’s Mission, to educate people on diabetes. 

“The American Diabetes Association is thrilled to work with Ryan Reed on the Drive to Stop Diabetes awareness campaign,” said Larry Hausner, Chief Executive Officer, American Diabetes Association. “As someone living with type 1 diabetes, Ryan is an inspiration to all of us and will be a passionate voice in raising awareness about diabetes in communities across the country.”

In addition, there will be a mobile movement which will focus attention on educating the community about the various types of diabetes. Through Ryan’s Mission, a 501c3, 100 percent of all net-proceeds raised will be donated to the Association.

“I am so excited to have the opportunity to work with the American Diabetes Association to help give back to those in the diabetes community by creating awareness and educating people on this disease,” Ryan Reed said. “I’m fortunate to be able to do this using a platform that I’ve worked for since the age of four, which is auto racing. I was told two years ago that I wouldn’t be able to achieve my dream of being a NASCAR driver, and now I’m making my debut for Roush Fenway Racing in the No. 16 Drive to Stop Diabetes Ford Mustang Nationwide Series car at Richmond. That just shows life has no limits.”

 

P!ss off, Belichek. You were ignorant when you were in Cleveland, and you are still ignorant today. It's nice some things never change.

http://www.diabetes.org/for-media/2013/nascar-driver-ryan-reed.html

‎05-16-2013 09:07 PM

 According to Pro Football Focus' run defense metrics among defensive tackles, Love was the 22nd most effective player at his position in the league last year

 

Unfortunately, I suspect that will be the excuse they use. How much his then-undiagnosed condition had to do with that is hard to say.

 

It stinks, because now that he is aware of it and can treat it properly he should be able to return to full fitness and effectiveness. Hopefully he will be able to convince another club of that.

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.

‎05-17-2013 09:56 AM - edited ‎05-17-2013 09:56 AM

Thank you all for sharing this story. Part of the Association’s mission is to end discrimination against people with diabetes, and we work to help individuals who have faced discrimination. To learn more, please call 1-800-DIABETES or visit http://www.diabetes.org/discrimination

 

Best,

Anna

Anna Baker (ADA_AnnaB)
Community Admin and Director, Digital Engagement
American Diabetes Association
http://www.diabetes.org

I am a bookworm, reluctant runner and mother of two young children!

Feel free to email community@diabetes.org if you have questions about the community or the variety of programs and online resources available from our Association. Please note, however, that I myself do not have diabetes and am not a medical professional.
